Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: just learned about some history really. The whole class was basically story time and it was awesome.
I learned how and why history formed since the 1500s due to military, economic, and political events.
A greater understanding of the interplay of technology and economy in the growth of global powers
More historical background of the rise of the West.
General history of how military affects societies in broad strokes.
Learned a lot about how warfare has changed and developed since 1500 throughtout the world.
Focused on breadth, and overarching themes. Gave me a better idea of how the military got to where it is now.
I learned a lot about military history, specifically naval, land, and air power since the 1500s until present day.
I gained insight into military history and the factors that don't immediately register as military that contributed to the rise and fall of great powers.

I gained a sweeping overview of military history of the West since 1500, covering economic, political, and social factors that impacted the big picture. This course takes on a mammoth task of a broad subject in a massive time period, but if you attend lectures and do the readings, you will have an understanding about why and how Europe ended up in its current state and how it has interacted with non-European powers over the last several centuries.

Great overview of western history through the lens of warfare. While it goes through a lot of content, it is not as rigorous in terms of testing your understanding as other history courses, which makes it more accessible as non-majors.
Lot of knowledge about military and normal history since 1500. I learned how to track themes and trends throughout history well.
Military History

This class gives a general knowledge of world, military history over the last 600 years. I personally find the arts of war a very intriguing subject that is essential in understand the way the world is today. Great class.
Learned more broadly about military history
Knowledge of the Western rise narrative.

It's exactly what you expect. An overview of a history which few other Yale courses focus on. Given the way the department has been trending in recent years, few students, myself included, know much about military history. As a history major, it seemed important to engage with one of the oldest forms of history, even if some people consider it to be decreasingly relevant. Kennedy is a very engaging lecturer, and the entire course really is just attending lecture and listening. If you do that, you'll be fine on the two exams, which are your entire grade. Honestly, even if you don't do that you'll be fine if you take the time to study for a day or two. It's a class that can be completed without attending lecture, but one you may enjoy going like I did.
Military history of west
This course helped me gain a rudimentary understanding of military history and how the adoption of different military technologies impact military force and national hegemony
This course was a great insight into a long period of western history, focussing in detail on particular wars and revolutions, whilst also covering a huge amount.
The different social, political, geographical, economic, etc factors that all factor in to the rise and fall of nations and why.
a good understanding of military history from fifteen hundred to the present day.
I learned a bit about the military history of the west, and the general trends of the last 500 years, but I did not learn very much about history as a field.
I gained a much deeper understanding of post 1500 European history.
I learned a broad overview of military history and some basic power shifts in Europe over the last five centuries.
learnt amore about the rise and fall of powers since 1500 - i knew little about it before
I learned about the military strategy and history from 1500-2000.
Not much. Didnt really learn much since theres no work. A lot of memorization for the exam which went straight out the window approximately 30 minutes after.
Learned about military theory and military history of the West, which ultimately gave rise to the West from 1500 onwards.
I learned about the main technological, strategic and financial innovations that have shaped the course of warfare, and how these were reflected by the outcomes of major conflicts throughout history.
This class gives a broad picture of history since 1500.

The class teaches you about overarching trends in military history. Important topics include the impacts of geography on history, how war and bureaucracy effect each other, and how moneys importance to war has impact history.

Overview of military history from the late 14th century to today. Focus on the economic and technological basis of military power, in line with Kennedy's thesis in his "The Rise and Fall of the Great Powers." Examination of land, sea, and air power. Some interesting guest lectures about airpower in general, as well as British naval history. You will have a better feel for the overall trends of Western history, even if the details start to fade a little bit by the end.
Engaging
I learned about military history, how to read history books, and how to write an essay that uses military events as evidence.
Better idea of how to use sources
Developed my knowledge of military, economic , political and technological factors from 1500 to present
A broad survey of the military developments from about 1500 to present. It is quite cursory and the lectures do not cover much, unfortunately.

Overview of military history in the West since 1500 (big surprise). In some ways though, this class felt like a European/Western history class with the flavor of military history as opposed to the other way around. This was probably better actually, since you get to learn about all the different factors that inform military decisions and continuities. Essay writing and argument generation (thinking critically) was improved for the sake of the exams.
I gained great knowledge of military history since 1500.
Great overview of military history.
I learned basic military history covering events from the Spanish Armada to Gulf War I. The course is a lot of reading, but the reading is inherently interesting.
I developed my ability to synthesize large amounts of information into a cogent argument.
Military history! Lots of it
Knowledge of important moments in military history and the major players involved.
Insight into the various military strategies during Western history starting from the 1500s.
I learned more history regarding the time period specified in the course. The history had a focus on relationships between economics and military.
this class taught me how to study history effectively and prioritize readings
How the west rose and fell in terms of military might, and how finance, technology, and geography affected it.
I learned the basics of military history.
Particularly enjoyed the theme of how war and militaries are paid for.
A broad overview of the ways in which Military history has shaped Global History.

This class was a fascinating class. It is not focused on individual battles and the tactics that were applied in them, but rather to the interactions between militarys, technology, and economic forces. I learned a lot about the sweep of Europian history after the 1500's
I learned a lot about the history of Western militaries since the 16th century and how it has helped shape the overall history of civilizations.
Knowledge generally of the topic
Make the TA grading consistent. This class is so wildly dependent on your TA. As a science major thats super annoying to me. My TA was a ruthless grader.
you can space out very quickly but it really isnt a big deal
Great professor, interesting readings. There could be another assignment throughout the semester so the final isn't worth so much.

You're old that lectures are optional, but they're absolutely worth going to! I just wouldn't make that policy as clear. Readings are a bit dense and repetitive at time, but I think that the pace and breadth of the course was fantastic. A good complement to other political science courses of the time.
Lectures were too general in its information scope.

Pros: relaxing class, low workload, interesting assigned readings
Cons: not offered at the same time each year; bounces around.
Material should be more specific with readings connecting more to lecture. Sections are kinda pointless in the fact that making students summarize readings does not do much.
Super long readings, and interesting lectures, but that didn't have a lot of specific examples. I really enjoyed the guest speaker on Vietnam and after.
Lecture is interesting if you care at all about the subject, but it's definitely a lower workload class.
No weaknesses. Kennedy is a strength. The content is fascinating.

I thought this course was absolutely incredible. Its syllabus is well-organized and fascinating. If a student does the readings and attends lecture, they will have a wealth of knowledge and understanding of the subject. This course covers content that could fill several hundred courses and does it seamlessly. I do think that the lectures could be less vague and thematic and present more historical facts.

I loved the material.

There were huge disparities in terms of Section quality and TAs, as certain TAs were extremely helpful in organizing the lecture and readings, while others did not provide much direction as well.
The lectures also did not reflect the high quantity readings that were required.

Strengths: teaching and instruction was excellent. Section was good. Content was very interesting and professor Kennedy does a great job of creating individual stories for each slide. 
Weaknesses: It would help if from time to time the professor or the TAs would "zoom out" so to speak in order to help create the greater contextual story throughout history.
N/A
Engagement and expectations of TAs are extremely variable. Each section is run differently and each TA grades differently.
My TA made me despise this course, i normally would have enjoyed it but section was so dysfunctional and a complete waste of my time

the material, while broad, gives you a strong understanding of how the world came to be through military conflict over the last 600 years. However, your experience in this class is heavily influenced by your TA (as well as your grade). If you happen to get a 'know it all' TA who is going to be really strict, you honestly are better of either dropping the class or attempting to switch to a different TA.

Although Kennedy is good, the course is 100% dependent on your TA. Some of them are not very good, and it is pretty unfair distribution to the class. The TA does all your grading and your entire grade is in their hand which is a serious down side.

Strengths: interesting topics

Weaknesses: weight of grades, not much directional support
It is good that the course has exams which force students to cohere the narrative.

It is exactly what it intends to be  an overview of military history graded only in exams. A supposed weakness is it doesn't have papers, but it isn't a class about writing. It's strengths lie in the man. Kennedy knows what he's doing
There needs to be more structure to lectures; a lot of time it seemed like not much material was covered in lectures while there were long readings where it was hard to find out whats important.

I think this course was very intriguing and I enjoyed the material. However, I think that the amount of reading assigned is generally excessive and that the lectures are too broad. I wish that there was more overlap between the readings/section and what is covered in the lectures as this would greatly facilitate student's learning as well as preparation for the exam.
The large content of the course and lectures were both big advantages, but section was not very helpful for recapping and discussing the lectures.
Laurence Gaillard was very resourceful in terms of providing notes and compiling resources for her. We all benefited from this. However, there is a lot more she could improve on.

It's tough to follow lectures, what exactly we're meant to get from them. Sometimes they seem to be disconnected thoughts and ideas, but of course they are linked, it could be easier to link these together though. I think lecture organization is lacking that's all. Readings are also excessive in many days' schedules, and often lack strong connection to lectures.
The lectures were really interesting, but there wasn't really a clear format. There also wasn't a great organization as to what was expected of us in terms of facts of knowledge to be known.

Lecture is really unhelpful, Kennedy just points at slides that have pictures which he claims are "symbolic" of larger things, but provides no justification. At times felt like an art history class because he was showing, and talking about, so many paintings that seemed only somewhat related to our topic. He was descriptive at best, and never analytical. Often he would literally say nothing. The readings are also super long (90-150) pages a week and quite dense, as they're often filled with data and the intricacies of military phenomena. Most students I know did next to no readings. If you were to do all the readings you would learn a lot, and it would be very interesting, but there are way too many, and you would be completely unsupported by lecture or your TF so you may as well read the good ones by yourself.

The strengths lie in the material covered, as it is super important to study military history and European history. The weaknesses are in the fact that Professor Kennedys lectures didnt always seem to important and the readings were so long that people were usually not inclined to do them.

s - sections v helpful
w - slides sometimes sparse
Professor Kennedy's lectures were always amazing and section kept me engaged with the readings.
Weaknesses: there is virtually no work, so it doesnt make you learn the material as you go

The selection of historical events that the course covers is great. However, some of the readings are only very tangentially relevant to the course, and doing them had very little effect on my exam scores. Professor Kennedy's lectures are very slow and cover almost no material.

My TA, Laurence Gaillard, had several shortcomings that hugely impacted the course. She was reliably 10 to 15 minutes late to every section, then would spend at least 5 minutes trying to make the projector work (every single time). Partly as a result, her sections always overran by at least 10 minutes; she would neither acknowledge that class has ended nor dismiss us. The class usually consisted of two student presentations; after the first one, Laurence made a point of giving at least 10 minutes of personal feedback to the presenter, usually on a very specific point that she had a problem with, and which had absolutely no bearing on the rest of the class. Her own presentations were unclear, typically listing many individual events without comment or point.

Laurence is a harsh grader who gave the class a B- average at midterm and at least two Ds. My friend and I, who both had her as a TA and who had both done all of the readings, got a B+ and a B respectively; several of my friends who had neither read nor studied history before in college, but had different TAs, got As. This forced me to Credit/D the class, which was very disappointing since I had been taking it seriously. Her criticism of my essay was that she disagreed with the thesis.

Laurence has a lot of difficulty understanding the workings of an academic system to which she is not accustomed. She remarked that when she first graded our midterms, before reading the Yale grading guidelines (because clearly that's a reasonable order in which to do things), she gave a large number of grades below 40%, just because this is how things are graded in France. During exam preparation, she expected us to produce a 20 line description of Louis XIV for the IDs, even though he is at best tangential to the course; likewise for several other French figures who were barely mentioned. She assigned far more work than other TAs, expecting not only presentations but splitting us up into "reading groups" every week that were supposed to comment the presentations - if this sounds inane and poorly defined, it's because it was. She did not seem to understand that students were taking three to five other courses besides this one, and made it impossible to be successful in the class without approaching it as the main priority of one's semester. Between this and her late-starting, overrunning sections, it became clear that she had no respect for our time.

Laurence did not set clear goals. She took several weeks to grade the midterm and was still grading after our last section before spring break, making it extremely difficult for people to decide whether they should switch the course to Credit/D. After we came back, she gave some indication that the midterm grades might not be representative, but did not define what grading would be used - she rambled, "I will look at the top grade and say what I think it should be, and then grade like that, and the bottom grade will be the bottom grade" which mathematically does not mean anything. Rather, Laurence prefers to use weird and vague pedagogical methods, like writing the dates in our IDs in terms of the "quarter of century" they were in, which is not only stupid because saying Operation Barbarossa was in the second quarter of the twentieth century is useless, but also unhelpful to learning because nobody's brain works in terms of quarters of centuries. Why not just say there will be a five year tolerance on the IDs where appropriate? Everything was like this.

Finally, the grades for this course arrived two days after the Yale deadline for seniors; apparently professors and TA's do not have to care about deadlines that affect students' graduation.

I'll state the few positive aspects of this course first: it seems like the professors and TA really enjoy history, and some of the readings were rather interesting. However, this is where the positives begin and end. The bulk of issues I had with this course can be traced back to my TA, Laurence Gaillard. With no exaggeration, Laurence is the worst teacher I have ever had. She has absolutely no consideration for her students' time. She would come to section late, take an excessive amount of time to get the projector in the room to work, and consistently have us leaving late. Furthermore, she would assign additional work outside the bounds of what others in other sections would have to do, and uphold a standard for quality that would exceed what is normally expected in a Yale course. This is indicative in her grading as well. Initially, when grading the midterm, she had to regrade every exam, because she had no idea about typical Yale grade distributions, and had most of us failing or near failing. Her altered grades still had class averages far below many of the other TAs. I know several students in other sections who did not even purchase the books, yet managed to receive As on the exams, whereas in our section, with her level of preparation, class averages still circled around a B- or B. I normally would not overcomplain about the grading from a professor, as professors have the right to have any distributions they want. However, the students in our sections were doing over 100 pages of reading each week to prepare for her higher standards, yet managed to receive lower than normal grades, so I feel like this needs to be stated. I must also say, numerous people asked what she is looking for when grading exams, so as to not make the same mistakes, but she could not adequately provide objective standards for us to use when learning the material. Ultimately, I can only place so much of the blame on Laurence, as Pranav was the head TA, and should oversee all the TAs. The lack of standards among the TAs makes me question how well this class was organized. I wish this class was a lot better, and I usually would not even take the time to evaluate professors and TAs, but this experience was so poor that I felt compelled to let my opinion be known.
Super interesting material, and great lectures. Maybe the discussion section can be a bit more structured, although the TAs have done a great job.

Strengths: Paul Kennedy, learn a lot of material while not being too difficult, Interesting enough that i didnt fall asleep, and Paul Kennedy (he is a great lecturer).

Weaknesses: the grade is heavily weighted towards the essays on the midterm and finals. If you are taking this class to learn about all the important battles of history or the tactics or which exact model of gun was used at what time, this class isnt going to live up to your expectations. Kennedy focuses more on trends and lessons for this time period as well as taking a more surface view while only diving into such topics when necessary.

The reading was definitely interesting, and the subject matter certainly has a lot of potential. The guest lectures were also engaging. With that said, the normal lectures were often hit-or-miss: either very engaging or a little dry. More uniform grading across the TA's would also be helpful (same criteria across different sections. )
Taking tests
Professor Kennedy is an amazing lecturer and he is very knowledgable about the topics covered in class.

Slightly hard to engage with the teaching
Very interesting
Very strong course load and reading material. Maybe make lectures more engaging and more main idea topics discussed.

The lectures from about half-way through are quite weak. I recall one week where a list of wars post-1945 were just mentioned with little to no explanation via powerpoint. There is little to no grading uniformity and it is almost entirely dependent on your TA.

The class is quite easy, so long as you maintain a balance with the readings and have a good study guide for the exams. The lectures are always insightful, and sections often round out the particular topics of a given week. The class can get dull sometimes, especially if you aren't the most enthusiastic about Western history. The class could probably be improved if there were fewer readings -- or at the very least, all the readings were concentrated on the most important points.
This was a very interesting course. It could be improved with less reading as many of the readings overlapped.
Great professor. Not a gut, very difficult grading.

Having only two assignments is both a blessing and a curse for this course. The midterm seems easy, but the grading is not particularly generous. The final was also fair. This course might be improved by having more review sessions outside of class to try to digest the enormous amount of material presented.

While the lecture was quite large, section creating and enriching learning environment. The course was very broad and technology-focused rather than battle focused, which could be a positive or negative depending on your outlook. One area of improvement is organization. There were some lectures where I didnt understand the point that Professor Kennedy was trying to get across.
Wish it was more than just a midterm and a final because a lot of your grade ends up being decided by one test and you dont have the opportunity to show all that you have really learned

Very lecture heavy (which works well as Professor Kennedy is an excellent lecturer). The weekly reading was usually too much to keep up with, so a slimmer reading list of bare essentials with recommended reading wouldve been helpful.

I thought it would be helpful to shorten the readings, as I know that many students would end up just not doing them. I think shorter readings would encourage students to read everything and also not feel overwhelmed.

this class uses military history as a window into many areas of history, shedding light onto the entirety of the development of western civilization. the class was interesting, and professor kennedy was a great lecturer.
The course is very comprehensive already but it seems to omit certain aspects of military history that would be extremely helpful, such as political conditions, etc.
This course would be improved if there was more similarity across different sections.

Professor Kennedy is wonderful and I looked forward to his lectures each day. The readings were well chosen and the pacing was spot-on. The weakness is absolutely the variance among the TAs. Frankly, at least one of the TAs was focused on the wrong things and since grading is up to that one person, the student can easily be negatively affected by the bad luck of the draw. After trial and error, I ended up in a very good section with a great TA.
The course had excellent lectures and interesting reading, however, there was too much reading assigned for all the material to be covered in section. Also it might be worthwhile to assign an essay.

This class is very good. One weakness might be that at times it seems certain books are repetitive of other of the readings. However, in general I very much enjoyed the readings for this class (especially War Made New)
The lectures could get a bit drawn out and seem to provide miscellaneous information.

weaknesses: 
Sections varied widely in grading, material and rigor, very different experiences across sections and TAs
course material bounced back and forth in time
course material not organized well enough
too many readings, fewer would be more effective...also books are expensive
midterm essay was graded too harshly
presentations on certain topics by student s in section really helps with learning
Yes, Who doesn't love story time by an amazing professor
absolutely
Kennedy is a top-tier professor. Take it for him alone. Work isn't too challenging, a good fifth credit.
Only if they're not too interested in history, as it was pretty easy.
Definitely.  Low workload, an interesting subject, and a great professor makes it one of yale's gems.
Yes, very interesting material in class.
Yes. Not super hard, and a good overview.
Yes. Fascinating subject taught by an incredible professor

I would if you are looking for an easy humanity, but it's definitely not as easy as everyone says it is. You have to be prepared to do a lot of memorization for the final exam because it is cumulative and 60% of your grade. Also, your TA makes a big different in your grade.
This fundamentally changed my understanding of the world. If you don't take this class, you are missing out.

Absolutely! This course covers so much history, and even if you absorb a small fraction of it, you will have a better understanding of extremely important events and themes in history. This class is what you make of it, and you can only benefit from it.
If you really enjoy history, yes the material is extremely interesting.
Yes. A fascinating course with great material.
Yes
It is all about the TA. If you have an engaging, reasonable, and helpful TA, the class will be quite interesting. However, variability among TAs results in risk taking the class.
good class to take if you have a heavy workload schedule
Yes. It provides you a strong understanding of the key conflicts between world powers since 1500 and will allow you to gain a stronger understanding of why the world is the way it is today.

No. Kennedy is great and the lectures are fairly interesting, though sometimes dry. The sections are what are bad. My TA was pretty horrible, they just get people who do not know how to teach, organize, grade, or give feedback. If you get a bad TA seriously considered leaving because they control your entire grade.
No. The student could read the syllabus and obtain the course content.
Take this class for the right reasons. Its only problem is the disengaged students in section who clearly don't care
Yes, most of the knowledge is fairly surface level, though
yes
I would recommend this to any global affairs student looking for a history class that will inform their perspective on international security
Yes - it's an interesting and wide-ranging course and would recommend anything with Professor Kennedy.

No, no and no. Paul Kennedy is an amazing professor. However, this course is completely dependent on the TA you get. My TA was the worst TA I have ever had at Yale. I had Laurence Gaillard and she was absolutely the worst TA ever. I once fell in the bathroom and broke my leg. It was an extremely painful experience. I would rather break my leg again than ever have her as my TA ever again. I really hate to write this evaluation and it truly breaks my heart that I have to but this has to be said. I normally decline to write reviews but for this class, because of this TA, I just had to write a review. So, let me begin by outlining how this class is structured.  There are two lectures each week and one section. You select which section you want and are not allowed to switch after. You don't get to know who your TA will be before selecting which makes it a complete gamble. Before taking this course, I actually read some reviews on coursetable about how the TA you get for this class would determine your fate and that is so true. Now, about my TA. If there was a Nobel Prize for the worst TA, this TA would receive it every single year. If there was a Forbes list of worst TAs, she would be on it. If there was a Times 100 worst TAs in the galaxy, she would be on it. Laurence came late to section frequently (10-13 minutes), was extremely disorganized, extremely harsh at grading and would respond to emails a week late or never respond at all! We were all extremely shocked by her behavior. It reached a point where most of us would just come late to section as well because we knew she would come late! And when she did come late to section, she would go 10 minutes over time! Very inconsiderate of other students who had to go other sections right after hers. And when you tried to leave early when she was going over time, she would give you some look. My issue with her is not with the grading at all, I came into this course with a very strong military history and essay writing background so I did extremely well on the midterm (got an A) and found the final (grade pending) to be extremely easy as well. This class has two assessments. A midterm (30%), a final (60%) and participation (10%). For the midterm, almost half my section got Cs and Ds. Yes Cs and Ds. You read that right. Half the class. She said most people actually deserved Fs but she was being generous (aww thank you). However, grades are not my issue with her. I just felt that had to be mentioned for anyone who is pre-med/law or whoever cares about GPA a lot. Laurence was extremely disorganized. It was so unbelievable. If you set up an office hours appointment with her, you would be lucky if she came late because she most likely would not show up! Very inconsiderate of others! There are other specific instances I had with her but I dont want to go too much into detail and identify myself. This course is great but if you have Laurence as your TA, try and switch. If that doesnt work, drop the course! If you are looking for a Humanities credit, take Basic Drawing or The Rise and Fall of Atlantic Slavery (good guts, trust me). I know this evaluation might sound a bit dramatic but I promise you these comments arent exaggerated. Take this class next spring and have Laurence as your TA if you dont believe me. It was the STEM people in my section who really suffered with the grading. If you are a STEM person and choose to disregard my comments thats fine. But at least buy a coffin and make funeral arrangements for your gpa so that you can give it a proper burial after Laurence murders it. If you choose to not take it for a letter grade, be prepared for Laurence to completely miss out on your appointments or come extremely late and give you some weak excuse. Her extremely sloppy behavior really affected my mental health and I couldnt even fall asleep for most of the semester. In conclusion, I hope they do something about the TAs in this course. I'm sure Laurence only meant well.
Yes.
Very much yes. This class was amazing and very interesting. It's a great distribution or elective.

If you're looking for a fifth class, and want an easy B, then it's a good choice. You do not have to do any readings to get a B. But getting an A is not that easy, and you are super dependent on which TF you get. Some are very kind, and some will grade harshly. If you take history very seriously and want an engaging, analytical course, this is also not a good pick, as your lecturer and TF will do next to no analysis.
Yes: if they are interested in the subject, it is fascinating.
I definitely would, because Professor Kennedy is such a gem and the material is really interesting, even if the lectures dont always cover it well.
Great Credit/D. Don't need to show up to lecture to pass. Go to section though. Does a good job recapping lecture material.
yes - essential in understanding recent human world history

Useful for gaining a broad understanding of Western military history. Would only take this course if you can keep up with the readings, as the lectures focus primarily on overall themes of each time period, do not go into events in great detail.
Yes! Any student interested in the military or military history will benefit greatly from this course.

No. I found it very boring and the lectures were almost impossible to get through, even for people who enjoyed the material. If youre willing to do the 100 pages of reading each week, maybe then you could skip lecture but it seems hardly worth it. Even then, much of whats on the test is only in the readings and not covered in lecture, so who knows....
Yes, if you want to learn more about military history of the west!
I would not recommend this course to another student. You won't learn anything.
No way
yes
Absolutely, Kennedy is legend.

I would highly recommend this class. I think it should be mandatory for all history majors and have actually recommended this class to my friends who have elective credits/ need to fill their humanities. Paul Kennedy is a very interesting professor and would recommend any of his classes.

For sure. The material is very interesting, but how much you get out of this course is very much dependent on how much time you are willing to put into the readings. The grading depends on who your TA is (mine was kind of harsh).

Many of the other reviewers may talk about how you should take the course because Professor Kennedy, a famous historian, is teaching the course. While I do not criticize his incredible contributions to the field of history, the lectures are mind-bogglingly uninteresting, unorganized, and irrelevant to tests. The readings are surprisingly interesting, but so much is assigned that it is impossible to actually appreciate them all. Tests are completely decided by ones TA, and there are huge disparities between sections regarding average grade. There is 1 midterm and 1 final, thus there is almost no room for error, and the first time you ever get feedback is on the midterm worth 30% of your grade. This class is aborrently bad, and I would steer far far away. Please do not make the same mistake I did.
No
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. The topics are very interesting and the course gives an amazing overview of major battles and events.
yes - the content was very engaging and I'd recommend to anyone interested in the topic
Yes, amazing content.

No. Although the material is interesting, as the grading is almost entirely dependent on your TA it is unclear as to how you will do until the final. Unfortunately, the final is worth most your grade-- good luck.
If you like this kind of history, then yeah take it. The class is not difficult, so it can be a nice schedule round-out
I would recommend this course. There is a lot of reading and a lot of memorization required, but the class is very interesting and I took a lot out of it.
Yes if you are genuinely interested. Otherwise it is just a difficult humanities credit.

Yes, I would recommend this course to anyone looking for an interesting history class without any papers. People with an existing interest in military history will be very happy with Professor Kennedy's reading assignments, even if they are a little long sometimes.

Yes! Professor Kennedys course is enriching, interesting, and foundation-building with a relatively low workload. The class does require strong writing and synthesis skills to succeed, and furthermore studying and paying attention are absolutely necessary.
Yes! Overall it was interesting
Yes, I found it to be an engaging and insightful overview of a broad swath of history.
No. Also my TA was terrible and had no knowledge of the subject.
Yes, but the TA sessions are incredibly important to facilitating actual learning.
I would recommend this course to another student. In particular my TA was very good.
Yes! this class is a great introduction to the history department.
Depending on your TA, this course may or may not be a gut.

Professor Kennedy is wonderful. The lectures are humorous and engaging and I looked forward to class each day. So glad I took this, but as with most lectures, be very careful with your section choice as the quality of TAs varied greatly.
Yes, it is excellent for general knowledge even if you are not a history major.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in history at Yale. I am a STEM major, and I found this course very interesting and accessible.
I'd recommend this course to another student if they are interested in history or military developments.

Not generally, as the course is a mile wide and inch deep. Also confusing structure of material and too many readings. More assignments dispersed through semester would east stress and force students to study and learn incrementally.
Would absolutely recommend. This is a fantastic course.
